Welcome to the

EmojiVerse

Uncover the history and evolution of the fastes growing "language" in history,

as well as the meaning and usage of these characters today

  • 1999 Shigetaka Kurita creates emoji, a simple set of 176 ‚Äúpicture characters‚Äù or 12√ó12 pixel monochrome icons, meant to be sent alongside kanji or kana characters.
  • 2010 Emoji character sets are first incorporated into Unicode, a system for indexing characters. This standardization has allowed emojis to be used across different operating systems and by people around the world.
  • 2011 Apple adds an emoji keyboard to iPhones and other iOS devices, propelling more widespread adoption.
  • 2013 Android follows Apple‚Äôs lead, supporting emoji on their mobile devices as well. The word ‚Äúemoji‚Äù is also added to the Oxford English Dictionary.
  • 2014 Release of Unicode 7.0 includes approximately 250 emoji. Most of the new emoji characters were derived from widely used characters in Wingdings and Webdings fonts. However, Apple receives criticism in the form of a petition for only including two non-white faces. Established by Jeremy Burge, a member of Unicode‚Äôs emoji subcommittee and founder of emoji search engine Emojipedia, the first World Emoji Day takes place on July 17: the date was chosen because it appears on the emoji for "calendar" ( üìÖ ). (On this date in 2002, Apple announced its iCal calendar application for macOS.)
  • 2015 Unicode 8.0 adds another 41 emoji, including articles of sports equipment such as the cricket bat, food items such as the taco, signs of the Zodiac, new facial expressions, and symbols for places of worship. This release also includes five symbol modifier characters to provide a range of skin tones for human emoji. These modifiers are based on the Fitzpatrick scale for classifying human skin color. According to the Unicode Consortium, human emoji that are not followed by one of these five modifiers should be displayed in a generic, non-realistic skin tone, such as bright yellow, blue, or gray. (Corporate demand for emoji standardisation has placed pressures on the Unicode Consortium, with some members complaining that it had overtaken the group's traditional focus on standardising characters used for minority languages and transcribing historical records.)
  • 2016 With iOS 10, Apple announces that the gun emoji ( üî´ ) will be changed from a realistic revolver to a water pistol. Conversely, the following day, Microsoft pushed out an update to Windows 10 that changed its longstanding depiction of the gun emoji as a toy ray-gun to a real revolver. The original collection of 176 emoji is acquired by Museum of Modern Art.
  • 2017 ‚ÄúResearchers from the National Archives in Trencin, Slovakia claimed to found what they believe is the world‚Äôs oldest original emoji drawn by a lawyer called Jan Ladislaides ‚Äì‚Äù a smiley face dating from 1635.
  • 2018 ‚ÄúA group of advocates which include dating app Tinder, Reddit cofounder Alexis Ohanian and the founder of EmojiNation, Jennifer 8. Lee, are asking Unicode Consortium to add interracial couple emoji into its mix.‚Äù

Emoji Reader and Writer Sentiment

‚ÄúBecause emoji characters are treated as pictographs, they are encoded in Unicode based primarily on their general appearance, not on an intended semantic. In fact, when used as emoji, many of these characters acquire multiple meanings based on their appearance; for example, an emoji character for ‚Äúbank‚Äù which includes the letters ‚ÄúBK‚Äù has taken on in Japan the secondary meaning ‚Äúbakkureru‚Äù (a slang term for evading one‚Äôs responsibilities). The meaning of each emoji may vary depending on language, culture, and context.‚Äù
